newsitem.title: BELGIUM: BELGIAN PARLIAMENT BANS TOBACCO ADVERTISING.
newsitem.headline: BELGIAN PARLIAMENT BANS TOBACCO ADVERTISING.

text.p: The Belgian parliament on Thursday approved a law banning all tobacco and cigarette advertising and sponsorship from 1999.
A parliamentary spokesman said the law, mainly aimed at stopping the increase of smoking among youngsters, was passed by 89 votes to 22 with 29 abstentions.
"Smoking is a bigger killer than the daily traffic misery," Flemish socialist member of parliament Louis Vanvelthoven told BRTN radio.
Belgian BRTN radio said only France, Finland and Canada had similar strict bans on tobacco advertising.
Sporting groups are known to be worried about the effect the ban will have on events such as Belgium's leg of the Formula One motor racing world championship at Spa-Francorchamps.
The ban, due to come into effect on January 1, 1999, applies to roadside billboards, newspaper advertising and sponsorship of sports, cultural and musical events.
But it does not apply to areas where tobacco is traditionally sold -- newspaper and cigarette vendors -- and to foreign newspapers sold in Belgium.
The law also does not ban television sports coverage of tobacco-sponsored events organised abroad.
